data-size-converter.q1: How many MB in a GB?
data-size-converter.a1: 1 GB = 1,024 MB in binary (1024-based) calculation, which is the standard for storage.
data-size-converter.q2: What is the difference between MB and Mbit?
data-size-converter.a2: MB (megabyte) = 8 Mbit (megabits). Storage is typically measured in bytes, bandwidth in bits.
data-size-converter.q3: Does this use binary or decimal?
data-size-converter.a3: We use binary (1024-based) calculations, which is the standard for operating systems and storage.
data-size-converter.a4: Bytes, KB, MB, GB, TB, PB, Kilobits, Megabits, and Gigabits.
data-size-converter.a5: Yes, using precise binary conversion factors.

area-converter.q1: How many square feet in an acre?
area-converter.a2: A hectare is a metric unit equal to 10,000 square meters, commonly used for land area.
area-converter.a3: Square mm, cm, meters, hectares, sq km, sq inches, sq feet, sq yards, acres, and sq miles.
area-converter.q4: Is it accurate for real estate?
area-converter.a4: Yes, precise conversion factors suitable for professional land measurement.
area-converter.a5: Yes, completely free with unlimited conversions.

volume-converter.q1: How many cups in a gallon?
volume-converter.a2: Milliliters, liters, cubic meters, teaspoons, tablespoons, fluid ounces, cups, pints, quarts, and gallons.
volume-converter.q3: Are these US or imperial gallons?
volume-converter.a3: We use US customary units. US gallon = 3.785 L, Imperial gallon = 4.546 L.
volume-converter.a4: Yes, perfect for recipe conversions with precise results.

speed-converter.q1: How do I convert km/h to mph?
speed-converter.a1: Divide km/h by 1.609. For example, 100 km/h ≈ 62.14 mph.
speed-converter.a2: Mach 1 is the speed of sound, approximately 343 m/s or 1,235 km/h at sea level.
speed-converter.a3: A knot is one nautical mile per hour (1.852 km/h), used in aviation and maritime navigation.
speed-converter.a4: Meters/second, km/h, mph, knots, feet/second, and Mach number.

time-converter.q1: How many seconds in a day?
time-converter.q2: How many hours in a year?
time-converter.a3: Milliseconds, seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks, months, and years.
time-converter.a4: We use average values: 1 month = 30.44 days, 1 year = 365.25 days (accounting for leap years).

fuel-economy-converter.q1: How do I convert MPG to L/100km?
fuel-economy-converter.a1: L/100km = 235.215 / MPG (US). For example, 30 MPG ≈ 7.84 L/100km.
fuel-economy-converter.q2: What is the difference between US and Imperial MPG?
fuel-economy-converter.a2: Imperial gallons are larger (4.546 L vs 3.785 L), so Imperial MPG numbers are higher for the same vehicle.
fuel-economy-converter.a4: L/100km is an inverse measure — lower numbers mean better efficiency, unlike MPG where higher is better.

shoe-size-converter.q1: How does shoe size conversion work?
shoe-size-converter.a1: We convert based on foot length in centimeters, which is the universal baseline for all shoe sizing systems.
shoe-size-converter.a2: Shoe sizes vary slightly between brands. These conversions follow standard sizing charts and provide good approximations.
shoe-size-converter.a3: US Men, US Women, UK, EU (European), and centimeters (foot length).
shoe-size-converter.q4: What is the difference between US Men and US Women sizes?
shoe-size-converter.a4: US Women sizes are typically 1.5 sizes larger than US Men for the same foot length.

pressure-converter.q1: How do I convert PSI to bar?
pressure-converter.a1: 1 PSI ≈ 0.0689 bar. Enter the PSI value and select bar as the target unit.
pressure-converter.a2: Standard atmospheric pressure (1 atm) = 101,325 Pa = 14.696 PSI = 1.01325 bar.
pressure-converter.a3: Pascal, kPa, MPa, bar, atmospheres, PSI, mmHg, and Torr.
pressure-converter.q4: What is the difference between mmHg and Torr?
pressure-converter.a4: They are nearly identical. 1 Torr ≈ 1 mmHg (the difference is negligible for most purposes).

energy-converter.q1: How many calories in a kcal?
energy-converter.a1: 1 kcal (kilocalorie) = 1,000 cal. Food calories are actually kcal.
energy-converter.q2: How do I convert kWh to BTU?
energy-converter.a3: Joules, kilojoules, calories, kilocalories, Watt-hours, kilowatt-hours, BTU, eV, and foot-pounds.
energy-converter.a4: An electron volt (eV) is the energy gained by an electron through 1 volt potential difference.

number-base-converter.q1: How do I convert decimal to binary?
number-base-converter.a1: Enter the decimal number and select Decimal as the input base. The binary result appears automatically.
number-base-converter.a3: Yes, JavaScript handles integers up to 2^53 - 1 safely.
number-base-converter.q4: What characters are valid for hex?

roman-numeral-converter.a1: Standard Roman numerals support 1 to 3999 (I to MMMCMXCIX).
roman-numeral-converter.a2: Roman numerals use letters: I=1, V=5, X=10, L=50, C=100, D=500, M=1000. Subtractive notation (IV=4) is supported.
roman-numeral-converter.q3: Can I convert Roman to numbers?
roman-numeral-converter.a3: Yes, switch to "Roman to Number" mode and enter Roman numerals.
roman-numeral-converter.a4: Roman numerals have no representation for zero.

power-converter.q1: How do I convert HP to kW?
power-converter.q2: What is the difference between HP and PS?
power-converter.a2: HP (mechanical horsepower) = 745.7W. PS (metric horsepower) = 735.5W. PS is used in Europe.
power-converter.a3: Watts, kilowatts, megawatts, HP (mechanical), PS (metric), BTU/h, and foot-pounds/second.

gradient-generator.q1: What types of CSS gradients can I create?
gradient-generator.a1: You can create three types: linear gradients (with custom angle), radial gradients (circle shape), and conic gradients (rotating color sweep). Each type supports multiple color stops with adjustable positions.
gradient-generator.q2: How do I add more colors to my gradient?
gradient-generator.a2: Click the "Add Stop" button to add a new color stop. Each stop has a color picker, hex input, and position slider. You can add as many stops as you need and remove any stop (minimum 2 required).
gradient-generator.q3: Can I copy the generated CSS code?
gradient-generator.a3: Yes, the tool generates ready-to-use CSS code that you can copy to your clipboard with one click. The code uses the standard CSS gradient syntax supported by all modern browsers.
gradient-generator.a4: Yes, the gradient generator runs entirely in your browser. No internet connection is needed after the page loads, and no data is sent to any server.
gradient-generator.a5: A conic gradient creates color transitions rotated around a center point, like a color wheel. It is useful for creating pie-chart-like effects, loading spinners, and other circular color patterns.

palette-generator.q1: What color harmony modes are available?
palette-generator.a1: Six modes: Complementary (opposite colors), Analogous (neighboring colors), Triadic (three evenly spaced), Split-Complementary (base + two adjacent to complement), Tetradic (four evenly spaced), and Monochromatic (same hue, different lightness).
palette-generator.q2: How do I use the generated palette?
palette-generator.a2: Click any color swatch to copy its HEX code to your clipboard. You can also click "Copy All" to copy all colors at once. Use the HEX codes directly in CSS, Figma, Sketch, or any design tool.
palette-generator.a3: Color harmony refers to combinations of colors that are visually pleasing when used together. It is based on color theory and the relationships between colors on the color wheel. Harmonious palettes create balanced and professional-looking designs.
palette-generator.q4: Can I change the base color?
palette-generator.a4: Yes, use the color picker or type any HEX code in the input field. The palette updates instantly as you change the base color. Try different starting points to explore various color combinations.
palette-generator.q5: Is this tool free to use?
palette-generator.a5: Yes, the Palette Generator is completely free with no limitations. It works in your browser without registration, and you can generate unlimited palettes.

contrast-checker.a1: WCAG contrast ratio measures the relative luminance between foreground and background colors, on a scale from 1:1 (no contrast) to 21:1 (maximum contrast, black on white). Higher ratios mean better readability.
contrast-checker.q2: What are the WCAG AA and AAA requirements?
contrast-checker.a2: WCAG AA requires a minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text (18px+ bold or 24px+). WCAG AAA is stricter, requiring 7:1 for normal text and 4.5:1 for large text.
contrast-checker.q3: Why does color contrast matter for accessibility?
contrast-checker.a3: Many people have visual impairments including low vision, color blindness, or age-related vision loss. Sufficient contrast ensures that text content is readable by the widest possible audience, which is both a usability best practice and often a legal requirement.
contrast-checker.q4: How do I fix a failing contrast ratio?
contrast-checker.a4: Make the foreground darker or the background lighter (or vice versa). You can use our tool to experiment with different color combinations until you find one that passes the required WCAG level while maintaining your design aesthetics.
contrast-checker.q5: Does this tool support alpha transparency?
contrast-checker.a5: The current version works with opaque (solid) HEX colors. For transparent colors, the effective contrast depends on underlying layers. Test with the final rendered color for accurate results.

box-shadow-generator.q1: Can I add multiple shadow layers?
box-shadow-generator.a1: Yes, click "Add Shadow" to add as many layers as you need. Each layer has its own controls for offset, blur, spread, color, and opacity. Multiple shadows create depth and realistic effects.
box-shadow-generator.a2: An inset shadow appears inside the element instead of outside. Toggle the inset checkbox on any layer to create inner shadow effects, useful for pressed buttons or recessed areas.
box-shadow-generator.q3: How do I control shadow opacity?
box-shadow-generator.a3: Each shadow layer has an opacity slider (0-100%). This controls the alpha channel of the shadow color, allowing you to create subtle or bold shadow effects.
box-shadow-generator.q4: Can I copy the generated CSS?
box-shadow-generator.a4: Yes, click the Copy button to copy the complete box-shadow CSS property to your clipboard. The code is ready to paste into your stylesheet.
box-shadow-generator.a5: Spread controls how much the shadow expands or contracts. Positive values make the shadow larger, negative values make it smaller. Combined with blur, it creates various shadow shapes.

border-radius-generator.q1: Can I set different values for each corner?
border-radius-generator.a1: Yes, uncheck the "Link Corners" option to control each corner independently. You can set top-left, top-right, bottom-right, and bottom-left to different values for asymmetric designs.
border-radius-generator.a2: Three units: px (pixels, fixed size), % (percentage, responsive), and rem (root em, scales with font size). Choose the unit that best fits your project.
border-radius-generator.q3: How do I make a perfect circle?
border-radius-generator.a3: Set border-radius to 50% on a square element. Use the % unit and set all corners to 50% to achieve a perfect circle.
border-radius-generator.a4: When all corners are equal, the generator outputs a single value like "border-radius: 16px". When different, it uses the shorthand: "border-radius: TL TR BR BL" in clockwise order.
border-radius-generator.q5: Does this work with all browsers?
border-radius-generator.a5: Yes, border-radius is supported by all modern browsers including Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge. No vendor prefixes are needed.

glassmorphism-generator.a1: Glassmorphism is a UI design style that creates a frosted glass appearance using CSS backdrop-filter. Elements appear translucent with a blurred background, creating a sense of depth and layering.
glassmorphism-generator.q2: Is backdrop-filter supported by all browsers?
glassmorphism-generator.a2: Backdrop-filter is supported by all modern browsers including Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge. The generator includes the -webkit- prefix for maximum compatibility. Older browsers will show a solid background.
glassmorphism-generator.q3: How do I adjust the glass effect?
glassmorphism-generator.a3: Use the blur slider to control how much background blur is visible. Opacity controls the glass transparency. Saturation boosts the colors seen through the glass. Border opacity adds a subtle edge.
glassmorphism-generator.a4: Yes, use the two background color pickers to set the gradient behind the glass element. This lets you preview how the glass effect looks against different backgrounds.
glassmorphism-generator.q5: What CSS properties does it use?
glassmorphism-generator.a5: The effect uses background (with rgba for transparency), backdrop-filter (for blur and saturation), border (semi-transparent), and border-radius. All standard CSS properties.

animation-generator.a1: Eight presets: Bounce (up-down), Fade In (opacity), Slide In (left to right), Rotate (360° spin), Pulse (scale), Shake (horizontal), Zoom In (scale from 0), and Flip (3D Y-axis rotation).
animation-generator.q2: Can I customize the animation speed?
animation-generator.a2: Yes, use the duration slider to set the animation speed from 0.1 seconds to 3 seconds. Each preset has an optimized default duration that you can adjust.
animation-generator.a3: Timing functions control the acceleration curve of the animation. Linear runs at constant speed. Ease starts slow, speeds up, then slows down. Ease-in starts slow. Ease-out ends slow. Ease-in-out does both.
animation-generator.q4: How do I use the generated CSS?
animation-generator.a4: Copy the output which includes the @keyframes rule and the animation property. Paste the keyframes at the top of your CSS file and add the animation property to your element selector.
animation-generator.q5: Can I set how many times the animation runs?
animation-generator.a5: Yes, choose from infinite (loops forever), or 1, 2, 3, or 5 iterations. Use infinite for continuous effects like loading spinners, or a fixed count for one-time entrance animations.

clip-path-generator.a1: Eight shapes: Circle, Ellipse, Inset (rounded rectangle), Triangle, Pentagon, Hexagon, Star, and Arrow. Circle, ellipse, and inset have adjustable parameters. Polygon shapes are preset geometric forms.
clip-path-generator.a2: CSS clip-path defines a clipping region that determines which parts of an element are visible. Content outside the clip-path shape is hidden. It works on any HTML element including images, divs, and videos.
clip-path-generator.q3: Can I adjust the circle position?
clip-path-generator.a3: Yes, for circle and ellipse shapes you can adjust the center position (X and Y) and radius using sliders. The preview updates in real time as you make changes.
clip-path-generator.q4: Is clip-path supported by all browsers?
clip-path-generator.a4: Yes, clip-path with basic shapes is supported by all modern browsers including Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge. It is also hardware-accelerated for smooth rendering.
clip-path-generator.a5: Inset creates a rectangular clip with offsets from each edge (top, right, bottom, left) plus an optional border-radius. It is useful for creating rounded rectangles with custom insets.

flexbox-generator.a1: CSS Flexbox (Flexible Box Layout) is a one-dimensional layout method for arranging items in rows or columns, with powerful alignment and distribution capabilities.
flexbox-generator.a2: You can set flex-direction, flex-wrap, justify-content, align-items, align-content, and gap — all the key container-level flexbox properties.
flexbox-generator.q3: Can I copy the generated CSS?
flexbox-generator.a3: Yes, the tool generates clean CSS code that you can copy with one click and paste directly into your stylesheet.
flexbox-generator.q4: What is the difference between justify-content and align-items?
flexbox-generator.a4: justify-content controls alignment along the main axis (horizontal for row), while align-items controls alignment along the cross axis (vertical for row).
flexbox-generator.a5: Yes, the Flexbox Generator is completely free with no usage limits.

color-blindness-simulator.q1: What types of color blindness are simulated?
color-blindness-simulator.a1: We simulate protanopia (red-blind), deuteranopia (green-blind), tritanopia (blue-yellow blind), and achromatopsia (total color blindness/monochromacy).
color-blindness-simulator.a2: The simulation uses standard color vision deficiency transformation matrices widely used in accessibility research. Results closely approximate the actual perception.
color-blindness-simulator.q3: Why is this tool important for designers?
color-blindness-simulator.a3: About 8% of men have some form of color blindness. Testing your color choices ensures your designs are accessible and usable by all users.
color-blindness-simulator.q4: How many colors can I test?
color-blindness-simulator.a4: You can test between 2 and 10 colors simultaneously, making it easy to check your entire design palette.
color-blindness-simulator.a5: Yes, the Color Blindness Simulator is completely free with no usage limits.

palette-from-image.a1: All common image formats are supported including JPEG, PNG, WebP, GIF, BMP, and SVG.
palette-from-image.q2: How many colors can be extracted?
palette-from-image.a2: You can extract between 3 and 10 dominant colors from any image using the adjustable slider.
palette-from-image.q3: How does the color extraction work?
palette-from-image.a3: We use a k-means clustering algorithm on the image pixels to identify groups of similar colors and find the most representative dominant colors.
palette-from-image.a4: Yes, all processing happens in your browser using the HTML5 Canvas API. Your images are never uploaded to any server.
palette-from-image.q5: Can I copy the extracted colors?
palette-from-image.a5: Yes, you can copy individual hex codes by clicking on them, or copy all colors at once with the Copy All button.

font-pair-suggester.q1: How many font pairs are available?
font-pair-suggester.a1: We currently offer 12 professionally curated font pairs covering various design styles from elegant to tech to luxury.
font-pair-suggester.a2: Yes, all fonts are from Google Fonts — free to use in any web or print project with no licensing restrictions.
font-pair-suggester.q3: Can I copy the font import code?
font-pair-suggester.a3: Yes, you can copy both the CSS font-family declarations and the Google Fonts HTML link tag for easy integration.
font-pair-suggester.a4: We offer 12 style categories: elegant, modern, classic, bold, minimal, editorial, tech, traditional, professional, startup, impact, and luxury.
font-pair-suggester.a5: Yes, the Font Pair Suggester is completely free with no usage limits.

css-pattern-generator.a1: We offer 6 pattern types: stripes, dots, grid, checkerboard, zigzag, and diagonal stripes.
css-pattern-generator.a2: CSS patterns use CSS gradients (linear-gradient, radial-gradient, conic-gradient) with background-size to create repeating visual patterns without images.
css-pattern-generator.a3: Yes, you can set two colors and adjust the pattern size using intuitive controls. Changes appear instantly in the live preview.
css-pattern-generator.a4: Yes, CSS gradient patterns scale perfectly at any screen size and resolution since they are vector-based.
css-pattern-generator.a5: Yes, the CSS Pattern Generator is completely free with no usage limits.

password-strength-checker.a1: Strength is calculated using entropy (bits of randomness), character diversity (4 types), length, and checks against common passwords and patterns.
password-strength-checker.q2: Is my password sent to a server?
password-strength-checker.a2: No. All analysis happens locally in your browser. Your password never leaves your device.
password-strength-checker.a3: A strong password is at least 12 characters long, uses uppercase, lowercase, digits, and symbols, and avoids common words or patterns.
password-strength-checker.a4: Entropy measures randomness in bits. Higher entropy means more possible combinations, making the password harder to crack. 80+ bits is considered very strong.
password-strength-checker.q5: Why does it flag common passwords?
password-strength-checker.a5: Common passwords appear in breach databases and are the first ones attackers try. Even a long common password provides zero real security.

hmac-generator.a1: HMAC (Hash-based Message Authentication Code) is a cryptographic construction that uses a secret key and a hash function to produce an authentication code.
hmac-generator.a2: SHA-256 is the most common choice, offering a good balance of security and performance. Use SHA-512 for maximum security.
hmac-generator.q3: Is HMAC the same as hashing?
hmac-generator.a3: No. Regular hashing only ensures integrity. HMAC uses a secret key, so it also ensures authenticity — only someone with the key can produce a valid HMAC.
hmac-generator.a4: Yes. All computation uses the Web Crypto API and runs entirely in your browser. No data is sent to any server.
hmac-generator.a5: HMAC is used in JWT tokens, API authentication (AWS Signature), webhook verification (GitHub, Stripe), TLS, and many other security protocols.

aes-encrypt-decrypt.a1: AES-256 is considered unbreakable by brute force with current technology. It is used by governments and military organizations worldwide.
aes-encrypt-decrypt.q2: Can I decrypt on another device?
aes-encrypt-decrypt.a2: Yes. Copy the encrypted output and paste it on any device with this tool. Use the same password to decrypt.
aes-encrypt-decrypt.q3: What happens if I forget the password?
aes-encrypt-decrypt.a3: The data cannot be recovered without the password. There is no backdoor or recovery mechanism.
aes-encrypt-decrypt.q4: Is my data sent to a server?
aes-encrypt-decrypt.a4: No. All encryption and decryption happens locally in your browser using the Web Crypto API.
aes-encrypt-decrypt.a5: PBKDF2 (Password-Based Key Derivation Function 2) converts your password into a strong encryption key using 100,000 iterations of hashing with a random salt.

crc32-checker.a1: CRC32 (Cyclic Redundancy Check 32-bit) is a checksum algorithm that produces a 32-bit (8 hex character) value used to detect data corruption.
crc32-checker.a2: No. CRC32 is designed for error detection, not security. Use SHA-256 or similar for cryptographic purposes.
crc32-checker.a3: CRC32 is used in ZIP archives, PNG images, Ethernet frames, MPEG-2 streams, and many other formats for integrity checking.
crc32-checker.a4: Yes, files up to 100MB are supported. The calculation runs entirely in your browser.
crc32-checker.q5: Why do I get different results for the same text?
crc32-checker.a5: Ensure you are using the same encoding. This tool uses UTF-8 encoding for text input. Trailing spaces or newlines can also change the result.

credit-card-validator.a1: The Luhn algorithm (also known as modulus 10) is a checksum formula used to validate identification numbers including credit card numbers.
credit-card-validator.q2: Is this tool safe to use?
credit-card-validator.a2: Yes. All validation happens locally in your browser. No data is sent to any server or stored anywhere.
credit-card-validator.a3: No. This tool only validates the number format. It cannot check if a card is active, has funds, or process any transaction.
credit-card-validator.q4: How does card type detection work?
credit-card-validator.a4: Card networks use specific number ranges (BIN/IIN). For example, Visa cards start with 4, Mastercard with 51-55 or 2221-2720.
credit-card-validator.q5: Why is my test card number invalid?
credit-card-validator.a5: The number must pass the Luhn checksum. Many randomly typed numbers will fail. Use known test card numbers from payment processor documentation.

totp-generator.a1: TOTP (Time-based One-Time Password) is an algorithm that generates temporary codes using a shared secret and the current time. It is the standard behind Google Authenticator and similar apps.
totp-generator.q2: Where do I find my secret key?
totp-generator.a2: When setting up 2FA, the service provides a QR code or a Base32 secret key (like JBSWY3DPEHPK3PXP). This is the key you enter here.
totp-generator.q3: Is this compatible with Google Authenticator?
totp-generator.a3: Yes. TOTP is a standard (RFC 6238). This tool generates the same codes as Google Authenticator, Authy, Microsoft Authenticator, and others.
totp-generator.a4: Yes. Everything runs locally in your browser. Your secret key is never stored or transmitted to any server.
totp-generator.q5: Why is my code different from my authenticator app?
totp-generator.a5: Ensure your device clock is accurate. TOTP codes depend on the current time. Even a few seconds of clock drift can produce different codes.

rsa-key-generator.q1: What key size should I use?
rsa-key-generator.a1: 2048-bit is the current standard minimum. Use 4096-bit for higher security. 1024-bit is considered weak and should only be used for testing.
rsa-key-generator.a2: Yes. Keys are generated using your browser native Web Crypto API with cryptographically secure random number generation. Nothing is sent to a server.
rsa-key-generator.q3: What format are the keys in?
rsa-key-generator.a3: Public keys use SPKI format, private keys use PKCS#8 format, both encoded as PEM (Base64 with headers). Compatible with OpenSSL and most tools.
rsa-key-generator.q4: Can I use these keys for SSH?
rsa-key-generator.a4: The generated keys are in PKCS#8/SPKI PEM format. You may need to convert them to OpenSSH format using ssh-keygen for SSH use.
rsa-key-generator.a5: Larger key sizes require finding larger prime numbers, which is computationally intensive. 4096-bit keys may take a few seconds to generate.

pbkdf2-generator.a1: PBKDF2 (Password-Based Key Derivation Function 2) is a standard algorithm (RFC 2898) that converts a password into a cryptographic key by applying a hash function many times with a salt.
pbkdf2-generator.q2: How many iterations should I use?
pbkdf2-generator.a2: OWASP recommends at least 600,000 iterations for SHA-256 as of 2023. Higher values are more secure but slower. 100,000 is a reasonable minimum.
pbkdf2-generator.a3: A salt is random data added to the password before hashing. It ensures that identical passwords produce different derived keys, preventing rainbow table attacks.
pbkdf2-generator.a4: All are password hashing algorithms. Argon2 is newest and recommended. bcrypt is well-established. PBKDF2 is the most widely supported and available natively in browsers.
pbkdf2-generator.q5: Is this secure for password storage?
pbkdf2-generator.a5: PBKDF2 with high iteration count and a unique salt per password is suitable for password storage, though Argon2id is now preferred for new applications.

xml-json-converter.a1: XML attributes are converted to JSON properties prefixed with @ symbol. For example, <item id="1"> becomes {"@id": "1"}.
xml-json-converter.a2: Yes, deeply nested XML structures are fully supported and converted to equivalent nested JSON objects.
xml-json-converter.a3: Repeated XML elements with the same tag name are automatically converted to JSON arrays.
xml-json-converter.a4: Yes, all conversion happens entirely in your browser. No data is sent to any server.

yaml-json-converter.a1: Supports objects, arrays, nested structures, strings, numbers, booleans, null values, comments, and inline JSON/arrays.
yaml-json-converter.q2: Can I convert complex nested YAML?
yaml-json-converter.a2: Yes, nested objects and arrays are fully supported in both conversion directions.
yaml-json-converter.a3: JSON output uses 2-space indentation. YAML output uses clean 2-space indentation with proper nesting.
yaml-json-converter.q4: Does it support YAML anchors and aliases?
yaml-json-converter.a4: Basic YAML structures are supported. Advanced features like anchors (&) and aliases (*) may require a full YAML parser.

html-entity-encoder.a1: All common named entities plus numeric ({) and hexadecimal ({) entities. Includes characters like &, <, >, ", copyright, trademark, and more.
html-entity-encoder.q2: When should I use HTML entities?
html-entity-encoder.a2: Use HTML entities when displaying special characters in HTML that could be interpreted as markup, such as < and > in code examples.
html-entity-encoder.a3: Yes, both decimal (€) and hexadecimal (€) numeric entities are decoded to their character equivalents.

json-path-evaluator.a1: Supports dot notation ($.key), bracket notation, array indexing ([0]), and wildcard (*) for matching all elements.
json-path-evaluator.q2: How do I access nested properties?
json-path-evaluator.a2: Use dot notation like $.store.book[0].title or $.data.users[*].name to navigate nested structures.
json-path-evaluator.a3: Yes, use * to match all elements at a level. For example, $.store.* returns all values under store.

csv-editor.a1: Comma (,), semicolon (;), tab, and pipe (|) delimiters are all supported. Choose the one matching your data format.
csv-editor.q2: Can I add or remove rows?
csv-editor.a2: Yes, in edit mode you can add new rows and columns, and delete rows using the delete button.
csv-editor.q3: How does it handle quoted fields?
csv-editor.a3: The parser correctly handles double-quoted fields, including fields containing commas and escaped quotes within values.

markdown-table-generator.q1: How do I change column alignment?
markdown-table-generator.a1: Click the arrow button (← ↔ →) below each column header to cycle between left, center, and right alignment.
markdown-table-generator.a2: Yes, use the row and column number inputs to add more rows or columns. Data in existing cells is preserved.
markdown-table-generator.q3: Is the output compatible with GitHub?
markdown-table-generator.a3: Yes, the generated Markdown table is fully compatible with GitHub Flavored Markdown (GFM) and most Markdown parsers.

sql-to-csv.a1: Standard INSERT INTO table (columns) VALUES (...) syntax. Supports multiple INSERT statements for the same or different tables.
sql-to-csv.a2: SQL NULL values are converted to empty strings in the CSV output.
sql-to-csv.a3: Yes, each converted table has a download button that saves it as a .csv file named after the table.

yaml-validator.a1: Detects tab characters, inconsistent indentation, unclosed quotes, invalid key characters, and basic structural issues.
yaml-validator.q2: Does it show line numbers for errors?
yaml-validator.a2: Yes, when an error is found, the exact line number is shown to help you quickly locate and fix the issue.
yaml-validator.a3: This validates YAML syntax, not Kubernetes schema. It ensures your YAML is well-formed, but does not check if the structure matches Kubernetes specifications.

javascript-minifier.a1: It removes comments, extra whitespace, and unnecessary characters to reduce file size while maintaining functionality.
javascript-minifier.q2: Is the minified code still valid?
javascript-minifier.a2: Yes, the minified code is functionally identical to the original. Only non-essential characters are removed.
javascript-minifier.q3: How much space does it save?
javascript-minifier.a3: Typically 20-60% depending on the amount of comments and whitespace in the original code.

html-minifier.a1: Removes HTML comments, extra whitespace between tags, and unnecessary characters to reduce file size.
html-minifier.q2: Does it affect how the page looks?
html-minifier.a2: No, minification only removes non-visual whitespace and comments. The rendered page looks identical.
html-minifier.a3: In rare cases with pre-formatted content. Always test the minified output to ensure it renders correctly.

json-diff.q1: What types of differences does it detect?
json-diff.a1: It detects added properties, removed properties, and changed values at any nesting depth in the JSON structure.
json-diff.a2: Yes, arrays are compared element by element, detecting additions, removals, and changes at each index.
json-diff.q3: Can I compare large JSON files?
json-diff.a3: Yes, but very large files (>1MB) may take a moment to process. The tool handles typical API responses and configs easily.

cron-parser.a1: Standard 5-field cron: minute (0-59), hour (0-23), day of month (1-31), month (1-12), day of week (0-6, Sunday=0).
cron-parser.a2: Yes, supports * (every), / (step), - (range), and , (list) in all fields.
cron-parser.q3: How accurate are the next run times?
cron-parser.a3: Very accurate. They are calculated based on the current system time and the cron expression rules.

chmod-calculator.a1: Owner can read, write, execute (7). Group and others can read and execute but not write (5).
chmod-calculator.q2: What is the difference between 644 and 755?
chmod-calculator.a2: 644 gives owner read/write, others read-only. 755 adds execute permission, typically used for directories and scripts.
chmod-calculator.a3: Almost never in production. 777 gives full permissions to everyone, which is a security risk. Use it only for temporary testing.

http-status-codes.q1: What do the status code categories mean?
http-status-codes.a1: 1xx: informational, 2xx: success, 3xx: redirection, 4xx: client error, 5xx: server error.
http-status-codes.q2: What is the most common error code?
http-status-codes.a2: 404 Not Found is the most well-known. 500 Internal Server Error is the most common server-side error.
http-status-codes.a3: 418 I am a Teapot is an April Fools joke from RFC 2324. It is defined but not expected to be used by actual servers.

json-to-typescript.a1: Strings become string, numbers become number, booleans become boolean. Objects generate new interfaces, arrays use element types.
json-to-typescript.a2: Yes, nested objects generate separate named interfaces with proper type references.
json-to-typescript.a3: Arrays of objects generate a typed array using the first element to infer the interface structure.

text-to-binary.a2: Yes, text is encoded as UTF-8 bytes. Multi-byte characters will produce multiple byte values.
text-to-binary.q3: How do I decode binary back to text?
text-to-binary.a3: Switch to Decode mode, paste the space-separated byte values, and select the matching format.

url-parser.q1: What URL components does it show?
url-parser.a1: Protocol, hostname, port, pathname, search/query string, hash fragment, username, and password.
url-parser.a2: Yes, query parameters are automatically URL-decoded and shown as separate key-value pairs.
url-parser.a3: No, it requires a full URL with protocol (e.g., https://). Relative paths cannot be parsed without a base URL.

color-converter.a1: HEX (#RRGGBB), RGB, HSL, HWB, and CMYK. All values update simultaneously when you change the color.
color-converter.q2: How accurate is the CMYK conversion?
color-converter.a2: The conversion uses standard mathematical formulas. For print-accurate CMYK, use ICC color profiles in professional software.
color-converter.q3: Can I enter RGB values directly?
color-converter.a3: Currently input is via HEX or the color picker. RGB and other formats are shown as output that you can copy.

slug-generator.a1: A slug is the URL-friendly version of a title, like "my-blog-post" in example.com/my-blog-post.
slug-generator.a2: Yes, accented characters are normalized to their ASCII equivalents (é→e, ñ→n, etc.).
slug-generator.a3: Hyphens (-) are the most common and SEO-friendly choice. Google treats hyphens as word separators.

word-frequency.a1: Each word is counted and shown as a percentage of total words. Results are sorted by frequency.
word-frequency.a2: Yes, use the minimum word length filter to exclude short words like "a", "the", "is".
word-frequency.a3: Yes, it recognizes words in most Latin-based alphabets including accented characters.

text-reverser.a1: Characters (reverses every character), Words (reverses word order), and Lines (reverses line order).
text-reverser.a2: Yes, word mode preserves the original whitespace patterns between words.
text-reverser.a3: Yes, it properly handles Unicode characters including emoji and multi-byte characters.

duplicate-remover.q1: How does it handle empty lines?
duplicate-remover.a1: Empty lines are preserved. Only non-empty duplicate lines are removed.
duplicate-remover.a2: By default yes. You can toggle case sensitivity to treat "Hello" and "hello" as duplicates.
duplicate-remover.a3: The first occurrence of each unique line is kept. Subsequent duplicates are removed.

text-sorter.a1: Alphabetical (A-Z), reverse alphabetical (Z-A), by length (shortest/longest first), numeric, and random shuffle.
text-sorter.a2: Numeric mode sorts by the numeric value at the start of each line, not alphabetically.
text-sorter.q3: Is the random sort truly random?
text-sorter.a3: Yes, it uses the Web Crypto API for cryptographically secure randomness.

unicode-lookup.a1: Character display, Unicode code point (U+XXXX), decimal value, UTF-8 byte encoding, and HTML numeric entity.
unicode-lookup.q2: Can I look up a character by code point?
unicode-lookup.a2: Yes, enter a value like U+0041 or 65 in the code point lookup field to find the corresponding character.
unicode-lookup.a3: Yes, emoji and other multi-byte Unicode characters are fully supported.

invisible-char-detector.q1: What invisible characters does it detect?
invisible-char-detector.a1: Zero-width spaces, BOM, soft hyphens, directional marks, word joiners, and other Unicode control characters.
invisible-char-detector.q2: How do invisible characters get into text?
invisible-char-detector.a2: They are often introduced by copying from web pages, PDFs, or word processors. Some are added by text editors.
invisible-char-detector.a3: No, normal line breaks (LF) and tabs are preserved. Only truly invisible characters are removed.

random-string-generator.a1: Yes, it uses the Web Crypto API (crypto.getRandomValues) which provides cryptographically secure random numbers.
random-string-generator.a2: Lowercase letters (a-z), uppercase letters (A-Z), digits (0-9), and symbols (!@#$%^&* etc.).
random-string-generator.a3: Yes, generate up to 100 random strings at once. Each one is independently random.

meta-tag-generator.a1: Meta tags are HTML elements placed in the head section of a webpage that provide metadata about the page to search engines and social media platforms.
meta-tag-generator.q2: Which meta tags are most important for SEO?
meta-tag-generator.a2: The most important meta tags are the title tag, meta description, robots tag, and canonical URL. Open Graph and Twitter Card tags are essential for social media sharing.
meta-tag-generator.q3: What is the ideal meta description length?
meta-tag-generator.a3: The ideal meta description length is between 130-160 characters. Search engines may truncate longer descriptions in search results.
meta-tag-generator.q4: Do I need Open Graph tags?
meta-tag-generator.a4: Yes, Open Graph tags control how your page appears when shared on Facebook, LinkedIn, and other platforms. Without them, platforms may display incorrect or incomplete information.

open-graph-generator.a1: Open Graph is a protocol created by Facebook that enables web pages to become rich objects in a social graph. It controls how URLs are displayed when shared on social media.
open-graph-generator.q2: What size should OG images be?
open-graph-generator.a2: The recommended OG image size is 1200x630 pixels. This provides optimal display across Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and other platforms.
open-graph-generator.q3: Do Twitter and Facebook use the same tags?
open-graph-generator.a3: Twitter has its own Card tags but will fall back to Open Graph tags if Twitter-specific tags are not present. It is best practice to include both for optimal control.

robots-txt-generator.a1: Robots.txt is a text file placed in your website root directory that tells search engine crawlers which pages they can or cannot access.
robots-txt-generator.a2: The robots.txt file must be placed in the root directory of your website, accessible at yourdomain.com/robots.txt.
robots-txt-generator.a3: Yes, using User-agent: * and Disallow: / will block all compliant crawlers from accessing any page. However, this is only a suggestion and malicious bots may ignore it.
robots-txt-generator.q4: Should I include my sitemap in robots.txt?
robots-txt-generator.a4: Yes, including a Sitemap directive in robots.txt helps search engines discover your XML sitemap, which improves crawling efficiency.

sitemap-generator.a1: An XML sitemap is a file that lists all important URLs on your website, helping search engines discover and index your content more efficiently.
sitemap-generator.q2: How many URLs can a sitemap have?
sitemap-generator.a2: A single sitemap can contain up to 50,000 URLs and must not exceed 50MB uncompressed. For larger sites, use a sitemap index file.
sitemap-generator.q3: How often should I update my sitemap?
sitemap-generator.a3: Update your sitemap whenever you add, remove, or significantly change pages on your website. For dynamic sites, automated generation is recommended.

keyword-density.a1: Keyword density is the percentage of times a keyword appears in your text relative to the total word count. It helps measure how focused your content is on specific topics.
keyword-density.q2: What is a good keyword density?
keyword-density.a2: A good keyword density is typically between 1-3% for primary keywords. Higher density may be seen as keyword stuffing by search engines.
keyword-density.a3: N-grams are phrases of N consecutive words. Bigrams are 2-word phrases and trigrams are 3-word phrases. Analyzing n-grams helps find important keyword phrases in your content.

serp-preview.a1: SERP stands for Search Engine Results Page. It is the page displayed by search engines in response to a search query, showing titles, URLs, and descriptions of matching pages.
serp-preview.q2: What is the ideal title tag length?
serp-preview.a2: Google typically displays the first 50-60 characters of a title tag. Titles longer than this may be truncated with an ellipsis in search results.
serp-preview.q3: Why does my search snippet look different than expected?
serp-preview.a3: Google may rewrite your title tag or meta description if it determines a different snippet would be more relevant to the search query. Writing clear, relevant meta tags reduces this likelihood.

schema-markup-generator.a1: Schema markup is structured data vocabulary (from schema.org) that helps search engines understand the content and context of web pages, enabling rich search results.
schema-markup-generator.a2: JSON-LD (JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data) is the recommended format for adding structured data to web pages. It is a script tag added to the HTML head section.
schema-markup-generator.q3: Will schema markup improve my rankings?
schema-markup-generator.a3: While schema markup does not directly improve rankings, it can earn rich snippets that increase click-through rates, which indirectly benefits SEO performance.
schema-markup-generator.q4: Where do I add the JSON-LD code?
schema-markup-generator.a4: Add the JSON-LD script tag in the head section of your HTML page, or just before the closing body tag. Google can process JSON-LD placed anywhere in the HTML.

readability-score.q1: What is the Flesch Reading Ease score?
readability-score.a1: The Flesch Reading Ease score rates text on a 0-100 scale. Higher scores indicate easier text. A score of 60-70 is considered standard, easily understood by 13-15 year olds.
readability-score.q2: What is the Gunning Fog Index?
readability-score.a2: The Gunning Fog Index estimates the years of education needed to understand a text. A score of 12 means high school level, while a score of 6 means easily readable by most people.
readability-score.q3: How can I improve my readability score?
readability-score.a3: Use shorter sentences, simpler words, and avoid jargon. Break long paragraphs into smaller ones. Use active voice instead of passive voice, and aim for one idea per sentence.
readability-score.q4: What readability score should I target for web content?
readability-score.a4: For web content targeting a general audience, aim for a Flesch Reading Ease score of 60-70 and a Flesch-Kincaid Grade Level of 7-8. This ensures content is accessible to most readers.

timezone-converter.a1: UTC (Coordinated Universal Time) is the primary time standard by which the world regulates clocks and time. It is essentially the same as GMT (Greenwich Mean Time).
timezone-converter.q2: Does this tool handle daylight saving time?
timezone-converter.a2: Yes, the converter uses your browser Intl API which automatically accounts for daylight saving time transitions.
timezone-converter.a3: We support 28+ major timezones covering all continents including Americas, Europe, Asia, Africa, Australia, and Pacific regions.

countdown-timer.q1: Will the timer work if I switch tabs?
countdown-timer.a1: Yes, the timer uses the system clock for timing so it remains accurate even when the tab is not active.
countdown-timer.q2: Does the timer make a sound when it finishes?
countdown-timer.a2: Yes, an audio notification plays when the countdown reaches zero to alert you.
countdown-timer.q3: Can I pause and resume the timer?
countdown-timer.a3: Yes, you can pause the timer at any point and resume it without losing your remaining time.

stopwatch.a1: The stopwatch displays time with centisecond (1/100 second) precision, using the browser high-resolution performance timer.
stopwatch.a2: Yes, click the Lap button while the stopwatch is running to record split times. Each lap shows both the total time and the difference from the previous lap.
stopwatch.q3: Will the stopwatch continue if I switch tabs?
stopwatch.a3: Yes, the stopwatch continues running in the background and shows the correct elapsed time when you return to the tab.

date-calculator.q1: Does this calculator account for leap years?
date-calculator.a1: Yes, the calculator correctly handles leap years and varying month lengths in all calculations.
date-calculator.q2: Can I calculate dates in the past?
date-calculator.a2: Yes, in Add/Subtract mode use negative numbers to subtract time from a date. In Difference mode, the order of dates does not matter.
date-calculator.q3: What units are shown in the difference?
date-calculator.a3: The difference is shown in days, weeks, months, years, hours, and minutes simultaneously.

week-number.q1: What is an ISO week number?
week-number.a1: ISO 8601 defines week numbering where weeks start on Monday and Week 1 is the week containing January 4th. A year has 52 or 53 weeks.
week-number.q2: Why does my week number differ from other systems?
week-number.a2: Different countries use different week numbering systems. ISO 8601 starts weeks on Monday, while the US system starts on Sunday.
week-number.a3: A quarter divides the year into four 3-month periods: Q1 (Jan-Mar), Q2 (Apr-Jun), Q3 (Jul-Sep), Q4 (Oct-Dec).

world-clock.q1: How many cities can I add?
world-clock.a1: You can add as many cities as you want from our list of 30+ timezones covering all major cities worldwide.
world-clock.a2: Yes, all clocks update every second to show the precise current time in each timezone.
world-clock.a3: Amber/warm backgrounds indicate daytime (6 AM - 8 PM local time) while indigo/cool backgrounds indicate nighttime.

pomodoro-timer.a1: The Pomodoro Technique is a time management method that uses a timer to break work into intervals (typically 25 minutes) separated by short breaks.
pomodoro-timer.q2: Can I customize the timer durations?
pomodoro-timer.a2: Yes, you can customize the work duration, short break, long break, and the number of sessions before a long break.
pomodoro-timer.q3: Does it automatically switch between work and break?
pomodoro-timer.a3: Yes, the timer automatically transitions between work sessions and breaks, playing a notification sound at each transition.

epoch-converter.q1: What is a Unix epoch timestamp?
epoch-converter.a1: A Unix epoch timestamp is the number of seconds that have elapsed since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 UTC. It is widely used in computing to represent dates and times.
epoch-converter.q2: What is the difference between seconds and milliseconds?
epoch-converter.a2: Unix timestamps in seconds are 10 digits (e.g., 1700000000) while milliseconds are 13 digits (e.g., 1700000000000). Our tool auto-detects the format.
epoch-converter.a3: The Year 2038 problem occurs because 32-bit systems store Unix time as a signed 32-bit integer, which overflows on January 19, 2038. Modern 64-bit systems are not affected.

twitter-card-preview.a1: Twitter Cards are meta tags that allow you to attach rich media experiences to tweets that link to your content, showing titles, descriptions, and images.
twitter-card-preview.a2: Twitter supports Summary (small thumbnail), Summary Large Image (full-width image), App (app install), and Player (video/audio) card types.
twitter-card-preview.q3: Do Twitter Cards work on X?
twitter-card-preview.a3: Yes, Twitter Cards continue to work on X (formerly Twitter). The meta tag format remains the same.

instagram-font-generator.a1: These fonts use special Unicode characters that look like different font styles. They are actual characters, not formatting, so they work anywhere text is supported.
instagram-font-generator.q2: Will these fonts work on all platforms?
instagram-font-generator.a2: Yes, since these are Unicode characters they work on Instagram, Twitter, Facebook, TikTok, WhatsApp, and any platform supporting Unicode.
instagram-font-generator.a3: Some Unicode font styles may not be readable by screen readers. Use them sparingly for decorative purposes and keep important information in regular text.

hashtag-generator.q1: How many hashtags should I use?
hashtag-generator.a1: Instagram allows up to 30 hashtags but 10-15 relevant ones typically perform best. Twitter works best with 1-3 hashtags. TikTok allows up to 100 characters of hashtags.
hashtag-generator.q2: Should I use popular or niche hashtags?
hashtag-generator.a2: A mix of both works best. Popular hashtags give exposure but have high competition. Niche hashtags have less competition and more targeted audiences.
hashtag-generator.q3: Can I customize the generated hashtags?
hashtag-generator.a3: Yes, enter your specific topic keywords and they will be combined with category-specific trending hashtags for a relevant mix.

social-image-resizer.a1: All common image formats including JPEG, PNG, GIF, and WebP. The output is always PNG for maximum quality.
social-image-resizer.q2: Will my image be uploaded to a server?
social-image-resizer.a2: No, all image processing happens entirely in your browser using the HTML5 Canvas API. Your images never leave your device.
social-image-resizer.a3: The tool uses cover-fit cropping, which scales and centers the image to fill the target dimensions while maintaining aspect ratio, cropping edges as needed.

emoji-picker.q1: How do I use copied emojis?
emoji-picker.a1: Click any emoji to copy it to your clipboard, then paste it anywhere using Ctrl+V (or Cmd+V on Mac). Works in any text field.
emoji-picker.q2: Why do some emojis look different on different devices?
emoji-picker.a2: Each operating system and platform has its own emoji design. The same Unicode character may look slightly different on Apple, Google, Microsoft, and Samsung devices.
emoji-picker.a3: We include emojis from the latest Unicode standard. Older devices or browsers may not display the newest emojis correctly.

bio-generator.q1: How long should a social media bio be?
bio-generator.a1: Instagram allows 150 characters, Twitter 160 characters, TikTok 80 characters. Our generator creates bios that fit within these common limits.
bio-generator.q2: Can I customize the generated bios?
bio-generator.a2: Yes, the generated bios are starting points. You can edit them after copying to make them perfectly yours.
bio-generator.q3: What fields should I fill in?
bio-generator.a3: At minimum, fill in your role and one passion/interest. The more fields you complete, the more personalized and varied your generated bios will be.

random-number-generator.a1: Yes, we use the Web Crypto API (crypto.getRandomValues) which provides cryptographically secure random numbers.
random-number-generator.q2: Can I generate unique numbers only?
random-number-generator.a2: Yes, enable the "Unique" option to ensure no duplicate numbers are generated in your set.
random-number-generator.a3: You can set any integer range. The generator supports numbers from negative to positive values.
random-number-generator.a4: Yes, enable the "Sorted" option to get your random numbers in ascending order.

random-color-generator.a1: You can view and copy colors in HEX (#FF5733), RGB (rgb(255, 87, 51)), or HSL (hsl(14, 100%, 60%)) format.
random-color-generator.q2: How many colors can I generate at once?
random-color-generator.a2: You can generate between 1 and 50 random colors at a time.
random-color-generator.q3: How do I copy a color?
random-color-generator.a3: Click on any color swatch to copy its value in the selected format to your clipboard.
random-color-generator.a4: Yes, colors are generated using the Web Crypto API for cryptographically secure randomization.

fake-data-generator.a1: No, all data is randomly generated using common name and address databases. No real personal information is used.
fake-data-generator.a2: Yes, you can export generated data as CSV or JSON files for use in your projects.
fake-data-generator.q3: How many records can I generate?
fake-data-generator.a3: You can generate between 1 and 100 records at a time.
fake-data-generator.q4: Can I choose which fields to include?
fake-data-generator.a4: Yes, you can toggle individual fields (name, email, phone, address, company) on or off.

barcode-generator.a1: We generate Code 128 (subset B) barcodes, which is one of the most common and versatile barcode formats.
barcode-generator.q2: Can I scan the generated barcodes?
barcode-generator.a2: Yes, the generated barcodes are standard Code 128 and can be scanned by any barcode reader.
barcode-generator.a3: Code 128B supports all standard ASCII characters including letters, numbers, and common symbols.
barcode-generator.q4: Can I customize the barcode size?
barcode-generator.a4: Yes, you can adjust the bar width (1-5 pixels per module) and the barcode height (30-300 pixels).

placeholder-image-generator.a1: You can download placeholder images in PNG, JPEG, or WebP format.
placeholder-image-generator.q2: What is the maximum image size?
placeholder-image-generator.a2: You can generate images up to 4096x4096 pixels.
placeholder-image-generator.a3: Yes, you can enter any custom text. If left empty, the image dimensions will be displayed.
placeholder-image-generator.a4: Yes, both the background color and text color can be customized using color pickers.

avatar-generator.a1: Avatars are deterministically generated from your input text using a hash function. The same text always produces the same avatar.
avatar-generator.a2: Two styles: Pixel (symmetric identicon grid) and Geometric (abstract shapes with overlapping circles and rectangles).
avatar-generator.q3: Can I use these avatars commercially?
avatar-generator.a3: Yes, the generated avatars are created algorithmically and are free to use for any purpose.
avatar-generator.q4: What is the maximum avatar size?
avatar-generator.a4: You can generate avatars up to 512x512 pixels.

data-generator.q1: What types of data can I generate?
data-generator.a1: You can generate four types: Users (name, email, age, city), Products (name, category, price, stock), Orders (customer, product, quantity, status), and Posts (title, author, likes, date).
data-generator.q2: How many rows can I generate?
data-generator.a2: You can generate between 1 and 200 rows per dataset.
data-generator.a3: You can export as CSV (for spreadsheets) or JSON (for applications and APIs).
data-generator.a4: Yes, the data uses realistic names, email formats, price ranges, and other contextual values.

svg-wave-generator.a1: An SVG wave is a scalable vector graphic that creates a wavy pattern, commonly used as a decorative background or section divider on websites.
svg-wave-generator.a2: Yes, you can set two colors for the gradient background and adjust the number of overlapping wave layers.
svg-wave-generator.q3: How do I use the wave on my website?
svg-wave-generator.a3: Download the SVG file and use it as a background image, or copy the SVG code and paste it directly into your HTML.
svg-wave-generator.a4: Yes, SVG graphics are resolution-independent and scale perfectly on all screen sizes and devices.

gradient-wallpaper-generator.a2: Yes, you can pick any colors using color pickers. You can use 2 to 5 gradient stops.
gradient-wallpaper-generator.a3: Adding noise creates a subtle grain texture on the gradient, giving it a more organic and modern feel.
gradient-wallpaper-generator.q4: Can I use these wallpapers commercially?
gradient-wallpaper-generator.a4: Yes, the generated wallpapers are created by you and can be used for any purpose.

invoice-generator.q1: How do I save the invoice as PDF?
invoice-generator.a1: Click the Print button and choose "Save as PDF" in your browser's print dialog.
invoice-generator.a2: We support USD, EUR, GBP, JPY, CAD, AUD, CHF, CNY, INR, and BRL.
invoice-generator.q3: Can I add tax to the invoice?
invoice-generator.a3: Yes, you can set a tax rate percentage and it will be calculated and displayed on the invoice.
invoice-generator.q4: Is there a limit on line items?
invoice-generator.a4: No, you can add as many line items as needed.

receipt-generator.a1: Yes, click the Print button to open your browser's print dialog. You can print directly or save as PDF.
receipt-generator.q2: Can I customize the store information?
receipt-generator.a2: Yes, you can set the store name, address, receipt number, and date.
receipt-generator.a3: Cash, Card, and Bank Transfer are available as payment method options.
receipt-generator.a4: Yes, you can set a tax rate percentage that will be calculated and displayed on the receipt.

privacy-policy-generator.q1: Is this privacy policy legally binding?
privacy-policy-generator.a1: This tool generates a template. We recommend having it reviewed by a legal professional to ensure compliance with your jurisdiction.
privacy-policy-generator.a2: Yes, you can toggle features like cookies, analytics, ads, newsletters, third-party services, and user accounts.
privacy-policy-generator.a3: The generated policy includes GDPR-relevant sections like user rights, but consult a lawyer for full GDPR compliance.
privacy-policy-generator.a4: Yes, you can download as a text file or copy the entire policy to your clipboard.

subnet-calculator.a1: CIDR (Classless Inter-Domain Routing) notation uses a slash followed by a number (e.g., /24) to indicate the number of bits in the network mask.
subnet-calculator.q2: What is the difference between network and broadcast address?
subnet-calculator.a2: The network address is the first IP in a subnet (all host bits 0), while the broadcast address is the last IP (all host bits 1).
subnet-calculator.q3: How many usable hosts does a /24 subnet have?
subnet-calculator.a3: A /24 subnet has 254 usable host addresses (256 total minus network and broadcast addresses).
subnet-calculator.a4: A wildcard mask is the inverse of the subnet mask. It is used in access control lists (ACLs) and routing protocols.

ip-converter.a1: Dotted decimal (192.168.1.1), decimal integer, hexadecimal (0x prefix), and binary (with or without dots).
ip-converter.a2: An IPv6-mapped address (::ffff:x.x.x.x) represents an IPv4 address in IPv6 format for dual-stack systems.
ip-converter.q3: How is IP converted to decimal?
ip-converter.a3: Each octet is treated as a byte, combined into a 32-bit unsigned integer. For example, 192.168.1.1 = 192*256^3 + 168*256^2 + 1*256 + 1.
ip-converter.q4: Can I input binary IP addresses?
ip-converter.a4: Yes, enter binary with or without dots separating octets (e.g., 11000000.10101000.00000001.00000001).

bandwidth-calculator.a1: Transfer time = (file size in bits) / (connection speed in bits per second). We convert all units to bits for accurate calculation.
bandwidth-calculator.q2: What is the difference between Mbps and MB/s?
bandwidth-calculator.a2: Mbps (megabits per second) measures network speed, while MB/s (megabytes per second) measures data throughput. 1 MB/s = 8 Mbps.
bandwidth-calculator.a3: This calculator gives theoretical transfer time. Real-world transfers include protocol overhead, so actual times may be 5-15% longer.
bandwidth-calculator.q4: What speed should I use for WiFi?
bandwidth-calculator.a4: Typical WiFi speeds range from 50-200 Mbps for WiFi 5 (802.11ac) and 200-1000 Mbps for WiFi 6 (802.11ax).

mac-address-generator.a1: A MAC (Media Access Control) address is a unique 48-bit identifier assigned to network interfaces, typically displayed as 6 hex pairs.
mac-address-generator.a2: The least significant bit of the first byte. When 0 (unicast), the address represents a single device. When 1 (multicast), it represents a group.
mac-address-generator.a3: The second least significant bit of the first byte. When set, it indicates the MAC was assigned locally rather than by the manufacturer.
mac-address-generator.q4: Can I use generated MACs for testing?
mac-address-generator.a4: Yes, these are ideal for testing, development, and virtual machine configuration. Use locally administered unicast MACs to avoid conflicts.

port-reference.a1: Well-known ports (0-1023) are assigned by IANA and used by common protocols like HTTP (80), HTTPS (443), SSH (22), and FTP (21).
port-reference.q2: What is the difference between TCP and UDP?
port-reference.a2: TCP provides reliable, ordered delivery with connection setup. UDP is faster but unreliable — used for streaming, DNS, and gaming.
port-reference.q3: Can a port use both TCP and UDP?
port-reference.a3: Yes, some services like DNS (port 53) use both TCP and UDP depending on the query type and response size.
port-reference.q4: How many total ports are there?
port-reference.a4: There are 65,535 ports available (1-65535). Ports 0-1023 are well-known, 1024-49151 are registered, and 49152-65535 are dynamic/private.

ip-range-calculator.a1: CIDR notation (e.g., /24) defines the network prefix length. A /24 gives 256 IPs, /16 gives 65,536 IPs, etc.
ip-range-calculator.q2: What is the maximum range I can list?
ip-range-calculator.a2: The tool lists individual IPs for ranges up to /24 (256 addresses) to keep the browser responsive.
ip-range-calculator.q3: What is the first and last IP?
ip-range-calculator.a3: The first IP is the network address (all host bits 0) and the last IP is the broadcast address (all host bits 1).
ip-range-calculator.q4: Can I copy all IPs at once?
ip-range-calculator.a4: Yes, use the "Copy all" button to copy the entire IP list with one IP per line.

user-agent-parser.q1: What is a user agent string?
user-agent-parser.a1: A user agent string is a text identifier sent by your browser with every HTTP request, containing information about your browser, OS, and device.
user-agent-parser.q2: Can I parse any user agent?
user-agent-parser.a2: Yes, paste any user agent string into the text area. The parser handles all major browsers and operating systems.
user-agent-parser.a3: The tool automatically loads your current browser's user agent string from navigator.userAgent for quick analysis.
user-agent-parser.a4: Blink (Chrome, Edge, Opera), Gecko (Firefox), WebKit (Safari), and Trident (Internet Explorer).

http-header-analyzer.q1: What security headers should I look for?
http-header-analyzer.a1: Key security headers: Content-Security-Policy, Strict-Transport-Security, X-Content-Type-Options, X-Frame-Options, and Referrer-Policy.
http-header-analyzer.q2: How do I get HTTP headers to analyze?
http-header-analyzer.a2: Use browser DevTools (Network tab), curl -I command, or paste headers from any HTTP response.
http-header-analyzer.a3: Headers are grouped by function: Security (protection), Caching (performance), CORS (cross-origin), Content (payload), and Info (server details).
http-header-analyzer.a4: CSP is a security header that controls which resources (scripts, styles, images) the browser is allowed to load, preventing XSS attacks.

exif-viewer.a1: EXIF (Exchangeable Image File Format) is metadata embedded in image files by digital cameras and smartphones. It includes information like camera model, date taken, exposure settings, and sometimes GPS location.
exif-viewer.q2: Which file formats contain EXIF data?
exif-viewer.a2: JPEG and TIFF files commonly contain EXIF data. PNG files typically do not store EXIF metadata.
exif-viewer.q3: Is my image uploaded to a server?
exif-viewer.a3: No, all processing happens entirely in your browser. Your images never leave your device.
exif-viewer.q4: Can I remove EXIF data from my photos?
exif-viewer.a4: This tool only reads EXIF data. To remove it, you can use image editing software or take a screenshot of the image.

file-hash-checker.a1: A file hash is a unique fingerprint generated from the file contents using a cryptographic algorithm. Even a tiny change in the file produces a completely different hash.
file-hash-checker.q2: Which hash algorithm should I use?
file-hash-checker.a2: SHA-256 is the most commonly used for file verification. SHA-1 is older and less secure. SHA-384 and SHA-512 offer stronger security.
file-hash-checker.a3: No, all hash computation happens in your browser using the Web Crypto API. Your files never leave your device.
file-hash-checker.a4: MD5 is not supported by the Web Crypto API and is considered cryptographically broken. We use SHA family algorithms which are more secure.

text-steganography.a1: Text steganography is the practice of hiding secret information within ordinary text so that only the intended recipient knows a hidden message exists.
text-steganography.a2: It uses invisible Unicode characters (zero-width space, zero-width non-joiner) to encode binary data within normal text. These characters are invisible but preserved when text is copied.
text-steganography.q3: Can the hidden message be detected?
text-steganography.a3: Yes, by someone who knows to look for zero-width characters. This is not encryption - it is concealment. For security, encrypt your message before hiding it.
text-steganography.q4: Does it work with all text formats?
text-steganography.a4: It works with any system that preserves Unicode characters, including most messaging apps, emails, and text editors. Some platforms may strip zero-width characters.

ssl-certificate-decoder.a1: PEM (Privacy Enhanced Mail) is a Base64-encoded format for storing certificates, keys, and other cryptographic data, enclosed between -----BEGIN and -----END markers.
ssl-certificate-decoder.a2: You can see the certificate version, serial number, signature algorithm, issuer, subject (CN, O, OU, C), and validity period.
ssl-certificate-decoder.a3: Yes, all decoding happens in your browser. No data is transmitted to any server.
ssl-certificate-decoder.a4: The tool can detect private keys but for security reasons only shows basic format information. Never share your private keys online.

csr-generator.q1: Is it safe to generate keys in the browser?
csr-generator.a1: Yes, the Web Crypto API uses cryptographically secure random number generation. Keys are generated entirely in your browser and never leave your device.
csr-generator.q2: What key size should I choose?
csr-generator.a2: RSA 2048-bit is sufficient for most use cases. RSA 4096-bit provides extra security. ECDSA P-256 offers equivalent security to RSA 3072 with smaller keys.
csr-generator.q3: What format are the keys in?
csr-generator.a3: Public keys are in SPKI (SubjectPublicKeyInfo) PEM format. Private keys are in PKCS#8 PEM format. Both are widely supported.
csr-generator.q4: Can I use these keys for SSL certificates?
csr-generator.a4: The public key can be used as part of a CSR (Certificate Signing Request) process, but generating a full CSR requires additional tools like OpenSSL.

ascii-art-generator.a1: ASCII art is a graphic design technique that uses printable characters to create images and text banners. It has been used since the early days of computing.
ascii-art-generator.a2: Letters A-Z, digits 0-9, and basic punctuation (! ? .). The tool automatically converts input to uppercase.
ascii-art-generator.q3: Can I use it in code comments?
ascii-art-generator.a3: Yes! ASCII art banners are commonly used in code comments, README files, and terminal output to create visual section headers.
ascii-art-generator.a4: You can choose from block (█), hash (#), star (*), at (@), dollar ($), and zero (0) characters.

morse-code-translator.a1: Morse code is a character encoding method using sequences of dots and dashes to represent letters, numbers, and punctuation. It was developed by Samuel Morse for telegraph communication.
morse-code-translator.q2: How do I separate words in Morse code?
morse-code-translator.a2: In Morse code, letters are separated by spaces, and words are separated by a forward slash (/). Our tool handles this automatically.
morse-code-translator.q3: Can I hear the Morse code?
morse-code-translator.a3: Yes! Click the Play button to hear the Morse code played as audio tones using the Web Audio API.
morse-code-translator.a4: Yes, the tool supports all letters A-Z, numbers 0-9, and common punctuation including period, comma, question mark, exclamation mark, and more.

regex-generator.a1: A regular expression (regex) is a sequence of characters that defines a search pattern. It is used for string matching, validation, and text manipulation in programming.
regex-generator.a2: g (global) finds all matches, i (case-insensitive) ignores case, m (multiline) makes ^ and $ match line boundaries, s (dotall) makes . match newlines.
regex-generator.q3: Can I use these patterns in my code?
regex-generator.a3: Yes! The patterns work with any programming language that supports standard regex syntax, including JavaScript, Python, Java, and more.
regex-generator.a4: Email addresses, URLs, phone numbers, IPv4 addresses, dates, hex colors, credit card numbers, and ZIP codes.

json-schema-generator.a1: JSON Schema is a vocabulary that allows you to annotate and validate JSON documents. It describes the structure, types, and constraints of your data.
json-schema-generator.a2: The tool examines each value in your JSON to determine its type (string, number, integer, boolean, null, array, or object). For arrays, it infers the item type from the first element.
json-schema-generator.q3: Which JSON Schema version is used?
json-schema-generator.a3: The generated schema uses JSON Schema draft 2020-12, the latest specification.
json-schema-generator.q4: Can I validate JSON against the generated schema?
json-schema-generator.a4: The generated schema can be used with any JSON Schema validator library in your preferred programming language.

api-tester.a1: Most failures are due to CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) restrictions. The API server must include appropriate CORS headers to allow browser requests.
api-tester.a2: GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE, HEAD, and OPTIONS are all supported.
api-tester.a3: Yes, set the Content-Type header to application/json and enter your JSON in the request body for POST, PUT, or PATCH requests.
api-tester.a4: All requests are made directly from your browser to the API endpoint. No data passes through our servers.

currency-converter.q1: Where do the exchange rates come from?
currency-converter.a1: We use the Frankfurter API which provides rates from the European Central Bank. Rates are updated daily on business days.
currency-converter.a2: We support 30 major world currencies including USD, EUR, GBP, JPY, CHF, CAD, AUD, CNY, INR, BRL, and 20 more.
currency-converter.a3: Rates are updated daily from the European Central Bank. For real-time trading rates, consult a financial institution.
currency-converter.q4: What happens if the API is unavailable?
currency-converter.a4: If live rates cannot be fetched, the converter falls back to approximate offline rates so you can still get estimates.
